#Text=Seville
#Text=Seville ( Spanish : Sevilla ) Andalucia 's capital .
#Text=With more than 700,000 inhabitants , and 1.6 million in the metropolitan area , it is Spain 's fourth city , dominating southern Spain .
#Text=With heritage from the Arabs and from the Age of Discovery , as well as the flamenco scene , Seville is a diverse destination .
#Text=Understand
#Text=The smooth , slow Guadalquivir River flows through Seville , known as Betis by the Romans and as Betik Wahd-Al-Khabir by the Arabs .

#Text=Since it is hard to navigate upstream from Seville , the cereal-producing region starts here , and Seville has been a busy port from Roman times , under Muslim rule , and exploding during the Age of Discovery .
#Text=As the monopoly was broken and Cádiz largely took Seville 's place , the city entered a period of relative decline .
#Text=In the 19th century Seville gained a reputation for its architecture and culture and was a stop along the Romantic " Grand Tour " of Europe .

#Text=Seville has built on its tourism industry since , playing host to the International Exposition in 1992 , which spurred the construction of a new airport , a new train station , a bullet train link to Madrid , new bridges and improvements to the main boulevards .
#Text=Tourist facilities are top-notch and the city is buzzing with festivals , color and a thriving nightlife scene .
#Text=By plane
#Text=Sevilla International Airport ( SVQ ) is about 25 minutes drive from the city center .

#Text=A bus service " Especial Aeropuerto ( EA ) " runs about every 30 minutes from just outside the " Arrivals " hall during most of the day ( though with longer gaps from 13:00 - 16:00 ) and costs € 4.00 .
#Text=Taxis are always available next to the bus stop and run on a fixed fare to Seville center , € 22 during the day and € 25 after 22:00 and on weekends/holidays .
#Text=Much controversy has been stirred by some taxi drivers trying to overcharge tourists , so be careful to pay no more than this if you are traveling into the city .
#Text=Other destinations outside Seville obviously cost more and are metered .
#Text=Tips are not necessary , though € 1 - 2 for polite , helpful service is appreciated .
#Text=Speed limits seem to be considered as kind of minimum speed by most taxi drivers .
#Text=La Parra International Airport ( XRY ) is 10 km from Jerez de la Frontera , on the way to Seville .
#Text=This airport is in a nearby city , and is used by discount airlines such as Ryanair ( from Frankfurt-Hahn London-Stansted ) .
#Text=The communication between Jerez de la Frontera and Seville is good , as it is connected by bus and train .
#Text=It is also possible to go by taxi or rent car .
#Text=Ryanair also flies to Sevilla International Airport , from more destinations than Jerez .
#Text=By train
#Text=High-speed AVE trains are great if time is of the essence , less than an hour from the wonderful city of Córdoba , less than three hours run from Madrid to Seville .
#Text=However , slower RENFE trains remain a bargain , and there is an overnight train that runs from Barcelona to Seville in under 11 hours .
#Text=Estación de Sevilla-Santa Justa ( Sevilla Santa Justa Station ) , Avda Kansas City , ☏ +34902432343 .
#Text=M - F 04:30-00:30 , Sa Su and holidays 05:15-00:30. On the eastern edge of Seville city centre .
#Text=Completed in 1991 , the station is the southern terminus of the Spanish high-speed AVE train service .
#Text=Has luggage lockers , cafés , and a tourist information centre .
#Text=Santa Justa also serves many of the principal stations in Andalucia , including ' Media Distancia ' trains to Cadiz , Jaén , and Malaga .
#Text=By car
#Text=Driving is also always an option for long distance travel in Spain , but is n't as convenient or as useful once in town .

#Text=Public transportation works fine in the city , and most of the main tourist points are located in a walk distance , so it is recommended finding a lodging with a garage or else researching the area for parking places before the trip .
#Text=Driving in the old city is tricky but possible .
#Text=There is a 45-minute limit on cars entering the old city M - Sa 08:00 and 22:00 .
#Text=It is enforced by license plate scanners placed at entrances to the old city .
#Text=There is a € 200 fine for exceeding this limit .

#Text=Your rental company will be sure to tack on its € 50 processing charge , not to mention the late fees that will accumulate due to the time it till take to receive the citation in your home country .
#Text=There is very cheap parking available across the street from Av. de Málaga , 12 .
#Text=The lot is unguarded and if there is not agent in the booth then the entrance to the lot is free of charge .
#Text=Do not give money to the panhandlers loitering outside pretending they are lot attendants .
#Text=If they have not receipt to give you then it s a scam .
#Text=Be sure leave absolutely nothing in the car .
#Text=Seville in general is known for car break-ins .
#Text=Another very common option is using carpooling such as BlaBlaCar , a safe transportation method used by many locals .
#Text=By bus
#Text=The Spanish bus service is amazingly punctual and comfortable with most having air-con and a toilet .
#Text=Getting to Seville from other cities in Spain can sometimes be only minimally longer than train ( but much cheaper ) .
#Text=Check out your options first with the helpful Information desk you will find inside any terminal .
#Text=The buses run regularly to/from most major cities , departing either from the near the river , or the near the University/Santa Cruz .
#Text=Sometimes the queue for buying ticket from the ticket office on a busy day might take up to 20 minutes or more .
#Text=El Rocio - Sevilla M - F 10:15 , Sa 10:45 , daily 15:15 , daily 18:15
#Text=Sevilla - El Rocio Sa 08:00 , Su 08:15 , M - F 09:30 , Sa Su 11:00 , daily 15:00 , M - F 17:00
#Text=Jerez - Sevilla
#Text=daily 08:30 13:00 14:30 22:45 23:30 ( M - Sa there is an extra bus at 08:40 )
